In the early 20th century, a new artistic movement called Cubism began to take form. One of the most influential artists associated with this movement was Marcel Duchamp. While Duchamp did not consider himself a Cubist, his work was greatly influenced by the movement and he helped to shape its development. Duchamp’s Cubist-inspired paintings challenged traditional notions of perspective and representation. His use of abstraction and flattened forms sought to create a new way of seeing the world. In doing so, Duchamp helped to redefine what art could be. While Duchamp is best known for his paintings, he also produced a number of significant sculptures, readymades, and works on paper. His innovative approach to art-making had a profound impact on the course of modern art and remains influential today.

He believed that the traditional idea of art was too limiting, and that the artist’s role was to challenge these conventions. Marcel Duchamp Biography

Marcel Duchamp was born in 1887 in Blainville, France. He began his artistic career as a painter but is best known for his readymades, a type of found object sculpture. In 1915, he created his most famous work, the readymade urinal he titled Fountain. The following year, he had a major solo show of his work at the New York Society of Independent Artists. Cubist Insights

In the early 20th century, cubist artists began to break down traditional ideas about perspective and representation in art. Instead of seeing an object as a single, unified whole, they began to see it as a collection of geometric shapes and forms. This shift in perspective led to a new way of seeing the world, and helped to shape the modern world as we know it today.

How Cubism Changed The Way We See Reality

Cubism’s message is that reality isn’t what we see in traditional paintings. Instead, cubists sought to depict the entire structure of objects in their paintings by using only observational techniques such as perspective and graded shading. It was important for them to show things as they are rather than just to show off what they appear to be. This approach was known as cubism, and it was a revolutionary new style of painting in the first half of the twentieth century.
